title: Tension Pneumothorax Management
stem: You are caring for Mr. Johnson, a 62-year-old male admitted following a motor vehicle accident. The patient has a chest tube connected to a three-chamber drainage system. Based on the EHR data, evaluate the patient's condition and determine the appropriate nursing interventions.

itemContext.SBAR:
14:00 Report:
Situation: Mr. Johnson, a 62-year-old male, admitted 2 hours ago post-MVA, is intubated and mechanically ventilated. He is increasingly restless and agitated.
Background: Admitted with multiple rib fractures and a right hemopneumothorax. A 28 French chest tube was inserted in the ED with an initial output of 300 mL of blood. His history includes COPD managed with inhalers.
Assessment: HR 140 bpm, BP 90/50 mmHg, RR 32 and labored, SpO2 88% on 100% FiO2. Trachea is deviated to the left. There are no breath sounds on the right side. Chest tube output is 10 mL in the last hour. Subcutaneous emphysema is palpable around the chest tube insertion site. ABG: pH 7.20, PaCO2 60 mmHg, PaO2 55 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L.
Recommendation: Suspect a tension pneumothorax. Request a stat chest X-ray and consider immediate needle thoracostomy.
itemContext.Labs: ABG: pH 7.20, PaCO2 60 mmHg, PaO2 55 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L
itemContext.Vitals: HR 140 bpm, BP 90/50 mmHg, RR 32 and labored, SpO2 88% (FiO2 100%)
itemContext.MAR: No continuous infusions. PRN orders available for morphine (pain) and propofol (sedation).

responseOptions.rationale: Needle thoracostomy is the priority intervention for a suspected tension pneumothorax. The patient's clinical presentation (tracheal deviation, absent breath sounds, hypoxia, hypotension) strongly suggests a tension pneumothorax, necessitating immediate pressure relief to allow for lung re-expansion and improved venous return. This intervention provides immediate relief while definitive treatment with a chest tube is prepared. ClinicalPearl: A tension pneumothorax can quickly lead to cardiovascular collapse if not promptly addressed.

responseOptions.text: Administer a bolus of IV fluids.
responseOptions.rationale: Hypotension in tension pneumothorax results from decreased venous return due to increased intrathoracic pressure. Administering IV fluids helps improve preload and blood pressure, stabilizing the patient hemodynamically. This intervention counteracts the decreased venous return caused by the pneumothorax. ClinicalPearl: Hypotension in the setting of a tension pneumothorax is a late and ominous sign.

While hypoxia is present, increasing FiO2 alone does not address the underlying lung compression caused by the tension pneumothorax. The pneumothorax impairs both oxygenation and ventilation, and relieving the pressure is the priority. Increasing FiO2 alone will not resolve the underlying mechanical issue. QuestionTrap: Students may focus on the low SpO2, but the priority is addressing the cause of the hypoxia.

responseOptions.text: Reposition the patient to a high-Fowler's position.
responseOptions.rationale: Repositioning does not address the underlying pneumothorax. While high-Fowler's may improve ventilation in some respiratory conditions, it will not relieve the pressure causing the tension pneumothorax. Immediate interventions are needed to relieve intrathoracic pressure. QuestionTrap: Repositioning is a general intervention and does not address the acute life-threatening condition.

responseOptions.text: Assess the chest tube for kinks or occlusions.
responseOptions.rationale: While chest tube assessment is important, it is not the priority in this rapidly deteriorating patient. The clinical picture suggests a developing or worsening tension pneumothorax requiring immediate intervention. Addressing the tension pneumothorax takes precedence over troubleshooting the existing chest tube. QuestionTrap: Focusing on the existing chest tube distracts from the more acute problem.

responseOptions.text: Prepare to administer PRN morphine for pain.
responseOptions.rationale: While pain management is important, it is not the priority. Addressing the life-threatening tension pneumothorax takes precedence. Furthermore, morphine may worsen respiratory depression. QuestionTrap: Pain management is a lower priority than addressing the immediate threat to life.

responseOptions.text: Notify the healthcare provider of the patient's condition.
responseOptions.rationale: Notifying the healthcare provider is essential for escalating care. While immediate actions are taken, informing the provider ensures coordinated care and consideration of further interventions. This ensures the provider is aware and can provide further orders or interventions. ClinicalPearl: Prompt communication is crucial in managing rapidly changing patient conditions.

clinicalPearls: Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention. Key signs include tracheal deviation, absent breath sounds on the affected side, hypotension, and hypoxia despite oxygen administration. Rapid recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent cardiovascular collapse. Always consider the possibility of a tension pneumothorax in patients with chest trauma or those on mechanical ventilation.
questionTrap: Many students may focus on the chest tube drainage or oxygen saturation, which are distractors. The key is recognizing the constellation of signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and understanding the need for immediate intervention to relieve the pressure. Don't be misled by focusing on isolated data points.
mnemonic: Tension Pneumothorax: "TNT" - Tracheal deviation, No breath sounds, Tension/Treat with needle thoracostomy!
references: Ignatavicius, D. D., Workman, M. L., & Rebar, C. R. (2020). Medical-surgical nursing: Concepts for interprofessional collaborative care. (10th ed.). St. Louis, MO: Elsevier.

Lewis, S. L., Bucher, L., Heitkemper, M. M., Harding, M. M., Barry, M. A., Roberts, D., & Zhou, Q. (2017). Medical-surgical nursing: Assessment and management of clinical problems. (10th ed.). St. Louis, MO: Elsevier.
